Award.AwardTitle: Comprehensive genetic dissection of a model highly complex trait in budding yeast

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Elucidating the connection between genotype and phenotype is critical to achieving new heights in agriculture, evolutionary biology, and medicine. In this project, our goal is to help characterize basic principles underlying the genotype-phenotype map by comprehensively dissecting a genetically complex trait in a "simple" model organism. Specifically, we will extend our ongoing research on variability in susceptibility to DNA damage in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We will use statistically powerful and high-resolution genetic mapping experiments to identify the dozens of genetic variants that cause differences in DNA damage tolerance among three strains. We will then study how these genes interact and exert their effects using genetic experiments and functional assays. Our work should produce one of the most detailed genetic characterizations of a highly complex trait to date, and could also provide new insights into how cells detect and repair DNA damage.

As part of our broader impacts on society, we will use the proposed research to train multiple PhD, undergraduate, and high school students. We will also work with Rebecca Cooper, who instructs four sections of AP Biology at Burbank High School, to develop multiple lab practicals in which we use heritable trait variation in yeast to help teach biology to high school students. Additional interactions with Ms. Cooper?s class will involve talking with students about career opportunities in science, as well as discussing the many impacts of biological research on everyday life. Lastly, we will use the proposed work as a vehicle to expose minorities to research through the USC GREU program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the genetic basis of complex traits is important for agriculture, evolutionary biology, and medicine. In this project, we used the model budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae to explore the genetic basis of an example complex trait--resistance to hydrogen peroxide. We comprehensively identified regions of the genome that contribute to hydrogen peroxide tolerance in the three possible crosses of three yeast strains. In total, we detected 64 regions of the genome that contribute to heritable variation in hydrogen peroxide tolerance. Identification of these loci allowed us to examine the extent to which these regions interact with each other. We found that these loci largely behave additively, though we also identified some small effect interactions among the loci.

 

In addition, our experimental design resulted in the identification of causal genomic regions at the resolution of individual genes or genetic variants. We found that a broad spectrum of cellular processes contribute to hydrogen peroxide tolerance, including DNA repair, scavenging of reactive oxygen species, stress-induced MAPK signaling, translation, and water transport. Consistent with the complex genetic and molecular basis of hydrogen peroxide tolerance, we characterized two examples where multiple distinct causal genetic variants underlie what appears to be a single causal genomic region.

 

As a follow up to this work, we also identified a specific chromosomal duplication that spontaneously arises and confers elevated hydrogen peroxide tolerance in some genetic backgrounds in the cross. Using chromosome-scale genetic engineering, we determined that the effect of this aneuploidy on hydrogen peroxide tolerance is largely due to a single gene. This gene, TSA2, encodes a stress-inducible thioredoxin peroxidase, an enzyme that detoxifies cells of reactive oxygen species, such as those generated by intracellular hydrogen peroxide. More generally, this work bolstered an emerging synthesis that the beneficial effects of changes in chromosomal copy number are typically mediated by one or a small number of genes.
